23.text: the evolutionary ascent of our species

27.text: from the last common ancestor with the chimpanzee,

42.text: less than 100.000 years ago, really less than 40.000 years ago,

114.text: So to investigate this possibility when I got interested in this mistery,

118.text: I went down to the Amazon, where there are still surviving shamanistic cultures today,

125.text: and where they drink the powerful visionary brew Ayahuasca,

129.text: of which the active ingredient is Dimethyltryptamine, DMT,

133.text: which is actually closelly related at the molecular level to Psilocybin.

138.text: Now normally DMT cannot be activated orally when we encountered it in the West,

147.text: There's an enzyme in our stomachs called monoaminoxidaze

151.text: which switches off DMT on contact.

156.text: But in the Amazon they've got round this problem.

158.text: And they say it was the spirits that taught them how to do it.

162.text: The DMT in the Ayahuasca brew is contained in these leaves

165.text: from a plant that they call Chacruna in the Amazon.

169.text: And there they mix it together with this vine,

172.text: and out of the 150.000 different species of plants and trees in the Amazon

176.text: this is the one that contains a monoaminoxidaze inhibitor,

180.text: which switches off that enzyme in our stomachs

184.text: and allows the DMT in the leaves when the two are maried together and cooked in water

188.text: to be absorbed orally, and takes us on a 4 hour journey

197.text: Now it's no joke to drink Ayahuasca.

201.text: The Ayahuasca brew has a foul taste.

206.text: Really, really hideous and a dreadful, dreadful smell.

210.text: And after you've drunk your cup, you'll find within 45 minutes or so

214.text: that your sweating, that you're feeling nauseous.

217.text: Pretty soon you may well be vomiting, you may well having diarrhea.

220.text: So, nobody is doing this for recreation.

225.text: And I'd like to add that I don't think any of the psychedelics should be used for recreation.

230.text: They have much more serious and important mission with humanity.

236.text: So we're not doing this for fun. But what draws people to Ayahuasca again and again

240.text: to brace themselves for this experience - and you do have to brace yourself -

243.text: is its extraordinary effects at the level of consciousness.

247.text: And one of those effects has to do with creativity.

250.text: And we can see the creative cosmogenic impulse of Ayahuasca in the paintings

254.text: of Ayahuasca Shamans from Peru, like the paintings of Pablo Amaringo here -

259.text: those richly saturated colors, the amazing visions that they reproduce -

264.text: and this creative impulse has also spread to western artists.

269.text: Many western artists now have been deeply influenced by Ayahuasca

273.text: and are also painting their visions.

276.text: And as these paintings show, another universal experience of Ayahuasca

280.text: is the encounter with seemingly intelligent entities which communicate with us telepathically,

287.text: and I am making no claim one way or another as to the reality status of these entities we encounter.

291.text: Simply that phenomenologically, in the Ayahuasca experience they are encountered

296.text: by people all over the world, and most frequently of all,

299.text: the spirit of Ayahuasca herself - Mother Ayahuasca - who is a healer

306.text: and although she is kind of the mother goddess of the planet

310.text: she seems to take a direct personal interest in us as individuals,

315.text: to heal our ills, to want us to be the best that we can possibly be,

319.text: to correct errors and mistakes in our behavior that may be leading us down the wrong path.

325.text: And this is perhaps why, and it's an untold story, really -

330.text: Ayahuasca has been fantastically successful in getting people off harmful addictions to hard drugs

337.text: such as heroine and cocaine. Jacques Mabit at the Takiwasi clinic in Peru,

343.text: brings heroine and cocaine addicts out there for a month,

346.text: gives them 12 Ayahuasca sessions and they have encounters with Mother Ayahuasca

350.text: during those sessions that lead them not to wish to take heroine and cocaine any more,

355.text: and more than half leave completely free of their addiction,

365.text: until the Canadian Government interviened and stopped his healing practice

369.text: on the grounds that Ayahuasca itself was an illegal drug.

375.text: Now I have some personal experience of this. I have not been addicted to heroine or cocaine,

380.text: but I had a 24 years non-stop cannabis habit.

384.text: This started off smoking the herb and laterally vaporizing it,

390.text: but the basic truth is that for 24 years I was pretty much permanently stoned.

396.text: And I enjoyed it, being stoned and I felt that it helped me with my work as a writter and

439.text: to choose to smoke cannabis if they wish to do so,

441.text: but I think I was overusing it, I think I was abusing it, not using it responsibly.

561.text: much more focused and much more efficiently as well,

566.text: and I began to be able to address those negative aspects of my behavior

587.text: And you know, that leads me to ask what is Death?

590.text: Our materialist science reduces everything to matter,

594.text: and materialist science in the West says we are just meat, we are just our bodies,

597.text: so when the brain is dead that's the end of consciousness,

600.text: there is no life after death, there is no soul,

602.text: we just rot and are gone.

609.text: that consciousness is the greatest mystery of science

613.text: and that we don't know exactly how it works.

615.text: The brain is involved in it in some way,

617.text: but we're not sure how. Could be that the brain generates consciousness

621.text: the way a generator makes electricity, if you hold to that paradigm,

629.text: but it's equally possible that the relationship -

630.text: and nothing in neuro-science rules it out -

645.text: that we are immortal souls, temporarily incarnated in these physical forms,

650.text: to learn and to grow and to develop.
